Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 01:28PM MarieKelly wrote: Shirlann wrote: "It doesn't do much good to try to prevent lung cancer (which at present you don't have) by missing a link in your breast cancer treatment (a condition you DO have)." In a very general sense, that's more or less true.  But that's not exactly what I meant in saying what I did because in my opinion, that's not true across the board for everyone equally.  My mistake, I should have made the statement more clear. The message I was trying to get across is that there is a very significant difference between having a high risk cancer vs a low risk cancer in regards to the weight of concerns about possible future side effects from any given treatment.  According to the few studies done thus far on the subject, radiation induced lung cancer in smokers doesn't rear it's ugly head until at least 10 years after the radiation. So essentially, when someone has an aggressive, high risk form of cancer which could possible kill them even sooner than 10 years if it's not completely brought under control, then worrying about a radiation induced lung cancer loses much of it's importance in making the decision on whether or not to undergo radiotherapy. Putting it very bluntly, it really doesn't matter what might happen due to radiation exposure 10 years or more from now if the cancer kills you before then.  So in a high risk situation, it's far more important to control the cancer NOW regardless of any potential concerns of what might happen as a consequence in the future. But it's a completely different risk vs benefit scenario for many with a small, low grade, low risk, node negative cancer who, in all probability, already recieved a surgical cure. If these kind happen to reoccur locally (and locally is all radiation is doing anything to control anyway), then the threat that this reoccurance might lead to distant, life threatening metastasis is far less than for the high risk type. So concerns about the possibility of a smoker developing lung cancer due to radiation exposure 10+ years from now in a person with these low risk profiles is a much greater concern because these are the people most likely to still be alive in 10+ years.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 04:44PM - edited Apr 20, 2010 04:47PM by MarieKelly Lula, My suggestion to you would be to have a lumpectomy to get whatever might be left of that area out and assuming you get clear margins that are wide enough, do nothing else except maybe (big maybe) tamoxifen. I wouldn't do watch and wait with only a biopsy as treatment - you need the cancer removed first..  You're talking here about a very small area of grade 1 DCIS and presumably, nothing more showing on that MRI by the sounds of it from what you wrote.  Grade 1 is non-aggressive and slow growing and could literally sit there for many years before becoming invasive - or never even become invasive at all. Very small size and grade 1 is as good as it gets with a DCIS diagnosis, Watchful waiting, once the primary area of concern has been adequately removed, is a very reasonable option for someone with your diagnosis. There is absolutely no rush is making your treatment decisions, so don't let anyone, especially your doctors, make you think differently. Take many months to decide if that's what you need to feel completely comfortable with your treatment decisions. Start reading and learning everything you can about grade 1 DCIS and grade 1 IDC and keep in mind when reading on this forum that others may not have the same kind of breast cancer as yours. All breast cancer is not the same - some really requires the big guns and cannons hauled out while some, like grade 1 DCIS, only needs a single little B-B shot.  If you feel that you ultimately may want nothing beyond a lumpectomy, ask your surgeon to remove the biopsy track during the lumpectomy surgery. Doing this is an added bit of benefit in decreasing the risk of local recurrence and is especially important in someone who refuses radiation after lumpectomy. If he/she refuses or gives even the slightest indication that it's uneccessary, then find another surgeon who understands the potential benefit of doing it. Radiation after lumpectomy is done primarily to decrease the risk that residual cancer cells might have been left behind in unclear or inadequately cleared surgical margins or in the biopsy track, . If the biopsy track is removed and the margins are clear and adequate, then radiation offers minimal to no real benefit because the recurrence risk is already very loiw - especially when the cancer is low grade.  I had just turned 49 when diagnosed with not only grade 1 DCIS, but grade 1 invasive ductal (IDC) as well. I was however, already in menopause. So at diagnosis, I already had invasive disease. Still, the only treatment I've had for this cancer is a wide margin lumpectomy with biopsy track removal and a single node removed for sentinel node biopsy (to check for possible lymph node involvment because of the invasive component). My diagnosis was over 6 years ago and except for the 3-4 weeks or so with post surgical discomfort, my life has gone on almost as if it never happened. You can't even tell by looking at the breast without looking very closely for the faint scar that I ever had a lumpectomy and even on mammogram, there's such minimal scar tissue that it's barely evident.  I get a mammogram once a year and a breast exam with my yearly physical - and that's it in total. Don't overreact. Take time. Educate yourself.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 06:01AM MarieKelly wrote:  Jane, Yes, Ki-67 and the mitosis score are similar in that they are both looking at how fast the cells are multiplying, but my understanding is that Ki-67 is a somewhat more sensitive/accurate test. Cells go through a number of phases as they multiply and Ki-67 is an antigen that is present in all phases of this cell cycle except the phase where the cell is resting and not multiplying. So in this test they use an antibody stain (MIB-1) that attaches to the Ki-67 antigen to identify the percentage of cells that have been stained. Among other things, you might also see this test on a path report called MIB-1 instead of Ki-67. It also could be that your pathologist didn't do this test and that's why you don't see it on the report. I'm not as familiar with the process on how they do the mitotic score. All I know about that is they look under a microscope scope and count how many cells they see dividing and then assigned it a score of 1, 2 or 3...with 3 being a tumor with the most cells that are actively dividing.

After all, we're talking here about standard of care treatment that has some significant potential aftereffects both short and longterm. For some with an aggressive form of breast cancer, a local recurrence of that cancer would offer yet another opportunity for metastatic disease to develop. When it's aggressive breast cancer, that additional opportunity needs to be avoided at all costs. And so for those people, the potential benefits of local control by radiation after lumpectomy makes sense because the potential benefits outweigh the potential risks. Just stop and think for a moment - if someone has an aggressive breast cancer which has a high probability of eventually causing their demise if it becomes metastatic, that person may not even be alive a decade or more later. Which then of course, makes the potential long term consequences of radiation essentially a moot point.  On the other hand, for those with non-aggressive breast cancer, and especially those with small tumors that were very likely to have been sugically cured, the prospect of still being alive in a decade or more to suffer the possible consequences of treatment are very, very high. In these situations, the ratio of potential benefit vs potential risk is far less favorable to the patient. If someone was cured of the breast cancer by it's surgical removal (and many are) then it becomes all risk and no benefit whatsoever for that person. If someone with a non-aggressive breast cancer has a local breast reoccurence because some bit of the original cancer was left behind, it's likely going to be the very same non-aggressive cancer the 2nd time around.  Unlike high grade breast cancer which sometimes can become distantly metastatic when the tumor itself is very tiny or even microscopic, grade 1 breast cancer is very unlikely to become metastatic until it's much larger in size, if at all. The potential risk from grade 1 breast reoccurence is miniscule in comparison to that from a high grade reoccurence. So yes, in my opinion, keeping a close watch on things would be much more preferably to assuming the risks of radiation - assuming of course, you've got wide, clean margins. You'll be hard pressed to find an oncologist to agree that it's a reasonable decision. They prescibe treatment according the care standards and unfortunately, the current standards call for everyone with invasive cancer to undergo post lumpectomy radiation irregardless of their individual circumstances. So if you stand firm in that decison, be prepared to make stand alone with it. As you can see from my bio line below, I too had a small grade 1 tumor of which about 60% was IDC and the other 40% DCIS. My surgeon got very wide margins (the specimen removed was something like 7.5 by 3.5 cm) and he even removed the biopsy track along with it. It's now been over 6 years since my lumpectomy WITHOUT radiation and without any hormonal therapy either. My most recent mammogram last month was again completely negative. Having a heart valve problem and being a lifelong smoker would have put me at even greater (much, much greater!) risk for consequences of left breast radiation, but I would have been given it anyway by the radiation oncologist I consulted with -  and without even so much as a second thought about it from him, had I not known enough to refuse it. Good luck to you in making your final decision, but again - don't expect the medical professionals to support you. It would be a rare one who does. You won't get very much support for it here either, because most people wouldn't dare act contrary to what they're being told to do by a medical professional even if their gut was telling them otherwise. Just human nature, I guess..

Division of Breast Diseases, Buenos Aires British Hospital, Argentina. juriburu@intramed.net.ar Comment in: Abstract The latest advances in diagnostic and therapeutic procedures for breast cancer have provided valuable technological breakthroughs. We report on three patients who presented with multicentric breast cancer diagnosed by stereotactic needle biopsy and treated by skin-sparing mastectomy. Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 02:39PM MarieKelly wrote: Chasinghope, You situation got me wondering - and since it's a horribly crappy day here and I've got nothing much better to do today, I decided to try and find an explaination. First of all, although your oncologist told you that the oncotype "doesn't access or account for the grade" of your tumor, I'm not so sure that's true. Yes, grade is not directly taken into account when determinining the recurrence score (RS). However, Oncotype is based on examining 21 genes. There are 5 control/reference genes and the other 16 are cancer related with 5 of those 16 genes specific to cell proliferation - so almost a third of the cancer related genes being looked at are about proliferation. Proliferation is how rapidly the cells divide and high grade tumors divide rapidly.  The mitotic count is one of the determinations made by a pathologist when assigning histologic tumor grade and the mitotic count is a measure of cell proliferation.  So, although the Oncotype test doesn't directly take someone's predetermined  tumor grade into consideration when calculating a recurrence score,  the genes associated with one of the 3 components of the Nottingham Grading System, which is the most commonly used system to determine tumor grade, is weighted heavily by Oncotype.   Now on to what got me interested - having a very low RS yet a grade 3 tumor. Everything I've ever read suggests that grade DOES correlates closely with the oncotype recurrence score. So in other words, those with grade 1 are most likely to have a low RS and those with grade 3 are most likely to have a high RS with grade 2 most likely to have a intermediate range RS. Obviously there are some, like yours, that don't correlate well.  So, in having had a pathologist assign a grade 3 to your tumor, it would be reasonable to expect that your RS would NOT be in the low range. Since it was in the low range, the question then becomes why the discrepancy? Here's something interesting I found - http://www.cap.org/apps/cap.portal?_nfpb=true&cntvwrPtlt_actionOverride=%2Fportlets%2FcontentViewer%2Fshow&_windowLabel=cntvwrPtlt&cntvwrPtlt%7BactionForm.contentReference%7D=cap_today%2Fcover_stories%2F0307brcancer.html&_state=maximized&_pageLabel=cntvwr "Collaborating with pathologists at West Virginia University, Dr. Bloom blindly assessed tissue blocks from 28 patients who had previously had Oncotype DX performed. "All 14 tumors that had a low recurrence score had high expression of PR and low expression of KI67 and did not overexpress HER2," Dr. Bloom relates. "So if you want to find people with a low recurrence score, it appears that you could do that with three immunostains. Those also correlate very tightly with tumor grade, AND LOW-GRADE tumors almost always fall into the low-recurrence category."  Dr. Bloom calls the four tumors with a high recurrence score "more interesting." One had 3+ expression of HER2 while a second did not express HER2 but had a proliferation index of greater than 50 percent. "In the other two cases IHC data would have predicted a low recurrence score," Dr. Bloom says. Both expressed PR and had a low proliferation index. His initial conclusion was that IHC found all tumors with a low recurrence score but may have missed two with high recurrence scores. However, detailed analysis of the two discrepant tumors showed something more intriguing. A key factor in both tissue blocks was a cavity from the patient's previous needle core biopsy. "So the block contained tumor, but also adjacent to the tumor itself we could see the needle track with inflammatory tissue including macrophages," Dr. Bloom says. "IN THE BIOPSY TRACT THERE WAS GRANULATION TISSUE PROLIFERATING LIKE CRAZY. SO LOTS OF CELL WERE EXPRESSING KI67, BUT THEY WERE NOT TUMOR CELLS." Dr. Bloom also notes that a minor component in the recurrence score is CD68 expression, a macrophage marker. "We saw numerous CD68-positive macrophages in the tumor block," he says, "but no tumor cells expressing CD68." Taken together, he believes these findings can explain the discrepancies between the recurrence score and IHC results. Both patients with discrepant results elected to receive chemotherapy, he told CAP TODAY, "even though without this test they would have received only hormonal therapy. There is no doubt in my mind that both of these patients were significantly overtreated." So here this Dr. Bloom has offered some insight into how a Oncotype tested tumor might erroneously appear to have a high RS  (due to seemingly high proliferation) because there was granulating tissue present in the specimen which was rapidly dividing (as granulating tissue normally does). In these 2 cases, Oncotype gave a high recurrence score which was apparently  inaccurate and if looked at closely enough, the reason becomes apparent.  Although your situation would be the polor opposite of these 2 cases described,  there's still got to be an explaination for yours just as there was with these two. So the take home message of my rainy day story is this - When there is an obvious discrepancy between expectations based on tumor characteristics and oncotype results and things don't jive, then something is amiss somewhere and it should be investigated further.   If I were you, I would definately get another pathology opinion (or maybe even two) to confirm that it's really a high grade tumor before consenting to chemo. If it happens that the Oncotype is correct, then the most likely explaination as to why RS is low is because the tumor is not high grade.  If I had to choose between believing the Oncotype score or believing the assigned grade, I would believe the Oncotype score. Histological grading is subject to a degree of interobservor variabilty - meaning that it's entirely dependent on how a particular pathologist calls it and that another might see it differently. Errors are inevitable when things are subjective. Oncotyping, while still subject to occassional errors as noted by Dr.Bloom is far more reliable, non-subjective and reproducible.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 10:47AM MarieKelly wrote: WinterStorm, Unless your doctors are telling you that lumpectomy is not a reasonable option in your case, there should be no reason why you can't keep the breast.  Many women opt for mastectomy (sometimes bilateral) even when they have a choice. Their reasons are varied - sometimes it's because they're at very high risk of an aggressive breast recurrence. Sometimes it's just because their level of fear is so intense that they just want one or both of them gone to minimize any future risk of breast recurrence  - sometimes despite that risk being very low.  Whatever the reasoning, don't assume it's mandatory unless your surgeon and/or oncologist says it is...and even then, obtain 2nd and 3rd opinions if you're not comfortable with the idea of having it done. A mastectomy, with or without reconstruction, is not always free of consequences as some here can attest to and some surgeons have a preference for doing them over lumpectomy even when they're not really necessary.  I was diagnosed with invasive ductal in 2/2004 - small and low grade.  I had a lumpectomy with very wide margins and being large breasted to begin with, the cosmetic result is so good that you couldn't tell it was every done by looking at me naked. Depending on where the tumor is located within the breast, how much tissue is taken and the skill of the surgeon, even those with smaller breasts can come out of the lumpectomy surgery essentially unchanged in appearance. I refused radiation and also refused tamoxifen and arimidex. It's been 6 and 1/2 years already since my diagnois and I've had no recurrence. Radiation after lumpectomy for invasive cancer is almost always recommended because it's the current standard of care, but it's not always really necessary in every case.  Some absolutely need it - many don't.  Most women with small, low grade tumors that have been removed with very wide, clear margins (perferably 1 cm or more) won't benefit at all from radiation because their cancer would not have reoccured anyway.  That's not to say another cancer couldn't or wouldn't develop somewhere down the road but some with initial low grade breast cancer like myself, are comfortable addressing that possibility only if and when it occurs. You make no mention of the specifics of your breast cancer other than it's IDC and hormone positive.  I suspect that maybe you don't know as yet. Find out the grade of your tumor which is one of the most important things you need to know. A biopsy report would have that information and your oncologist or surgeon would certainly know it. Then go from there in making your treatment decisions. If you don't know all the details, and especially the aggressiveness of the beast your dealing with, you can't possibly know what weapons are necessary and which are overkill.  If you're not sure that you want a mastectomy, then just have a lumpectomy for now. You can always do a mastectomy after a lumpectomy, but you can't ever go back and opt for a lumpectomy once you've done a mastectomy. If you have a lumpectomy and you think you might want to decline radiation, ask the surgeon to remove the biopsy track during the lumpectomy surgery. Some think it's a waste of time and unnecessary, some think otherwise. Mine removed my track and does so with every lumpectomy he does whenever possible. This gives one more added layer of protection (in addition to wide, clear margins) in decreasing the risk of local recurrence. Hope all my rambling helped!

Posts.Content: May 26, 2008 07:36PM MarieKelly wrote: Undifferentiated (also known as anaplastic) is essentially the equivalent of a grade 4.  Cancers are graded according to how closely they resemble the normal tissue from which they originate. The more they resemble normal cells, the more "differentiated" they are. grade 1 = well differentiated cells grade 2 = moderately differentiated cells grade 3 = poorly differentiated cells grade 4 = undifferentiated (anaplastic) cells  You'll need more than just the term "undifferentiated" to determine the stage, but just by knowing that a cancer has been labeled as undifferentiated tells you that it's very aggressive, likely to spread rapidly and that it's very likely to be hormone receptor negative. It's like a wildfire in the presence of strong winds...even a small one can rage out of control with it's embers being carried into neighboring areas if not dealt with swiftly and aggressively.
